"There are confirmed cases of COVID-19 in Afghanistan. National airports are open.  The Ministry of Public Health requires a negative PCR test, conducted within 96 hours of travel, for all incoming passengers.    People arriving from other countries and who do not show symptoms of COVID-19 are advised to self-quarantine at home for 14 days.  If you have any symptoms, you are instructed to contact the Ministry of Public Health and seek care."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210202072319/https://af.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No change since last week.    "There are confirmed cases of COVID-19 in Afghanistan. National airports are open. https://web.archive.org/web/20210202072319/https://af.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    "Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Afghanistan? Yes  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes  Testing is available at [...] laboratories in Kabul. The price is approximately $60-100 USD and results are provided in English"

NO change in policy. Schools remain closed at all levels: "Dipu Moni: Educational institutions will not reopen in March if Covid-19 risk remains: Education Minister Dr Dipu Moni on Wednesday said that educational institutions would not reopen even in March if health risks posed by the coronavirus pandemic continued."  https://archive.vn/GfzPA

"Currently, only certain sectors located within the Wari jurisdiction of the Dhaka South City Corporation are designated as ‘lockdown/containment’ zones. In these areas, the City Corporations will facilitate emergency response services.  Restrictions on Designated Lockdown/Containment Areas:  Pedestrian and vehicular movements controlled through secured entry/exit points.  Residents should remain within their homes except for emergencies or for essential needs.  No indoor dining services allowed. Delivery food service options are available.  Grocery stores and pharmacies will remain open.  Residents will be allowed to shop in bazaars only when necessary.  Residents must work from home.  Transportation will be suspended. Rickshaws, vans, taxis, auto-rickshaws, and private vehicles are not permitted inside the demarcated areas during the 21-day lockdown.  COVID-19 tests will be available to residents, and home isolation or institutional isolation will be arranged for patients who test positive.  Shopping malls, gyms, sports complexes and recreation centers will be closed.  No public gatherings of any kind are allowed.  Only people who are ill may go to hospitals.  Mosques and other places of worship are closed to residents. Only official staff are permitted to enter.  ATM services will remain open. Banks will operate in a limited capacity.  Factories in towns will remain closed, but factories and agricultural production-related factories in rural areas can remain operational.  Agricultural work must be performed under strict health and hygiene regulations."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210215095331/https://bd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

"Those arriving from, or transiting, the UK are required to quarantine at a government facility, or government approved hotel, where they will be tested for COVID-19 after seven days. Those testing negative for COVID-19 in that test will be allowed to complete the remainder of the 14 day quarantine period through ‘home quarantine’. Those testing positive will be transferred to a designated government hospital where their remaining quarantine period will be assessed and determined. The Bangladesh authorities will retain passports of passengers while they remain in quarantine and will return them at the end of the quarantine period. Passengers arriving in Bangladesh, from countries other than the UK (i.e. NOT the UK) need to quarantine for 14 days. Typically this can be completed as self-quarantine but health officials at the point of entry to Bangladesh will assess whether passengers are able to self-quarantine or need to be taken to a government facility. In all circumstances, people staying in a government approved hotel, government facility or hospital will need to cover the costs of those stays."  https://archive.vn/rjO8q

"Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Bangladesh?  Yes  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours?  Yes  For information on limited humanitarian exemptions, please review the following page: https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/traveladvisories/ea/covid-testing-required-us-entry.html  The Government of Bangladesh has provided a list of recommended COVID-19 testing facilities for international passengers here. Those wishing to get tested will have to pay for their own COVID-19 test."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210215095331/https://bd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No change in policy: https://archive.vn/NsUu9

"Fines for Non-Compliance:    As of July 23, 2020, the Government of Bangladesh will take legal action against those not wearing masks or social distancing. Since May 30, the Government of Bangladesh has made wearing masks and social distancing mandatory when outside the home. Public administrators in Khulna Division have instituted a fine of TK 4,000 for those not adhering to this order."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210215095331/https://bd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
See archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210125210114/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/asia-pacific/bangladesh-to-begin-covid-19-vaccinations-on-jan-27/2120387

A; Oxford University-AstraZeneca vaccine doses  Pilot Vaccine Drive started on Jan 28     "Bangladesh is expected to receive 12.5 million doses of the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine in the first half of 2021 under COVAX, the WHO-backed global scheme for distributing the coronavirus vaccines.  The two-day piloting was successfully carried out on January 28, but none of the 567 volunteers who took the first shot of the two-dose Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine has complained of any major side effect.  While the government`s target was to vaccinate 260,000 people each day, only 3,28,000 people got registered online in eleven days as of Saturday afternoon.  The doses will be administered in five stages under three phases. Priorities will be given to health workers and others on the frontline."  - https://archive.vn/ZxDLu#selection-1541.1-1488.58 "Bangladesh rolls out Covid-19 vaccine from Serum Institute of India", Feb 07, 2021    "The government is administering the Oxford University-AstraZeneca vaccine doses, manufactured by the Serum Institute of India, for free."   "More than 900,000 people have received their first dose of the coronavirus vaccine in Bangladesh in seven days since the mass inoculation began on Feb 7."   "Over 900,000 people take COVID vaccine in Bangladesh in seven days" - Feb 14 2021 - https://archive.vn/y1TCa#selection-1039.0-1042.0
No change as of Jan 31.  Some unlocking process was announced beginning Feb 1.

All schools will open as scheduled by the education ministry. Random testing for students and teachers will be carried out every two weeks. Health focal persons have been identified to monitor compliance and surveillance on campus.  (Press release on Unlocking Thimphu and beyond starting Monday (February 1, 2021)-PMO)  http://web.archive.org/save/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/29-01-21-press-release-on-unlocking-thimphu-and-beyond-starting-monday-february-1-2021-pmo/
No Change.

AnnouncementThis is to inform that all shops and business entities that were allowed to operate before the lockdown can now open in the two mega zones of North and South in Thimphu. This excludes night clubs, drayangs and karaokes.    Ministry of Health Web Archived: http://web.archive.org/web/20210201010224/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/27-01-2021-announcement-on-opening-of-shops-and-business-entities-in-the-mega-zones-of-north-and-south-in-thimphu-pmo/

All offices and institutions to open. The COVID-19 Safety focal office in all offices must ensure that all COVID-19 norms are in place and implemented.  All shops, restaurants and business entities can open.  The closure time is 9pm.  For hair saloons and barber shops, extra precaution to maintain proper hygiene and safety protocols will be imposed.  Mandatory COVID-19 testing every two weeks will be carried out.  Opening of entertainment centers of movie halls, clubs, karaokes and drayangs will be announced at a later date.  All sporting activities are allowed but without any spectators.  Closure time is 11pm.  No tournaments are allowed, unless approved by the Bhutan Olympic Committee.  For traditional games of archery and khuru, only 10 participants are allowed at a time.  (Press release on Unlocking Thimphu and beyond starting Monday (February 1, 2021)-PMO)  http://web.archive.org/save/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/29-01-21-press-release-on-unlocking-thimphu-and-beyond-starting-monday-february-1-2021-pmo/
Some region within Bhutan can open, but other remain closed    Bhutan Government Website: https://web.archive.org/web/20210222014916/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/5726-2/

No Change.     Ministry of Health Web Archived: http://web.archive.org/web/20210201010224/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/27-01-2021-announcement-on-opening-of-shops-and-business-entities-in-the-mega-zones-of-north-and-south-in-thimphu-pmo/

While gathering of any sort is discouraged, for community based religious congregation, a maximum of 25 people can participate. Prior approval must be sought from the local taskforce.  Religious gatherings at home must be limited to family members.  For funeral rites to be restricted to close circles.  Pilgrimage, menchu, tsachu and hiking are allowed.  For conferences, seminars, workshops and training, a maximum of only 25 people are allowed to gather.  The COVID-19 safety focal officers must maintain proper record of the attendees.  (Press release on Unlocking Thimphu and beyond starting Monday (February 1, 2021)-PMO)  http://web.archive.org/save/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/29-01-21-press-release-on-unlocking-thimphu-and-beyond-starting-monday-february-1-2021-pmo/
No Change.

Since Jan 28, Movement of lights vehicles and taxis are allowed within mega zones.    Ministry of Health Web Archived: http://web.archive.org/web/20210201010224/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/27-01-2021-announcement-on-opening-of-shops-and-business-entities-in-the-mega-zones-of-north-and-south-in-thimphu-pmo/

Inter-dzongkhag movement is allowed.  Public transports such as buses and taxis can operate.  Quarantine requirement from Thimphu and Paro is being lifted.  Seven-day mandatory quarantine will continue for those travelling from high risk to low risk areas.  All travellers must register with Check Post Management System (CPMS) prior to their travel.  Besides random testing of travellers along the check points, the public transport drivers will have to undergo mandatory testing every two weeks  (Press release on Unlocking Thimphu and beyond starting Monday (February 1, 2021)-PMO)  http://web.archive.org/save/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/29-01-21-press-release-on-unlocking-thimphu-and-beyond-starting-monday-february-1-2021-pmo/
No Change.
No Change.

the battle is only half won as we continue to sail through the pandemic, that too amid peak winter. We could regress into a situation far more disastrous if we let our guards down today.  Therefore, concerted efforts are being made to heighten surveillance along the borders and entry points with enhanced vigilance and improved operating procedures.  More tests for COVID-19 will be conducted among business communities, drivers, frontliners, students and health workers, while flu clinics will always scan for the early signs of the disease. Additional mobile flu clinics will be introduced in busy public places and certain points along the highways.  Above all, we are anticipating the roll out of the nationwide COVID-19 vaccination program that will protect our people and enable us to prevent the outbreak of the disease as we venture forward.  http://web.archive.org/save/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/29-01-21-press-release-on-unlocking-thimphu-and-beyond-starting-monday-february-1-2021-pmo/
No Change.

The government announced a National Resilience Fund for mitigating COVID-19 linked to job losses and salary cuts. The support included grant for individuals directly affected by the pandemic and full interest waiver on loans contracted since April 10, 2020 until June 2020. These measures were extended until September 2020, and partial (50 percent) interest waiver will continue until March 2021.       IMF Web Archived Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20210201002038/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

While Sri Lanka opened its borders to tourists this week, the ban on travelers from UK continues.    "Sri Lanka is set to re-open its borders to international tourists this month, and won't require visitors to quarantine during their holiday - but Brits have been left off the list for now." - https://web.archive.org/web/20210126062237/https://www.mirror.co.uk/travel/asia-middle-east/sri-lanka-welcome-back-tourists-23352448

"Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Sri Lanka? Yes  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes  S. citizens can obtain a COVID-19 test in Sri Lanka at any private hospital. The average cost per test is 9,000-13,000 Sri Lankan Rupees (approximately $50-$70).  Test results are forwarded via e-mail."   - https://web.archive.org/web/20210125130941/https://lk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    Additionally, multiple  new reports from Jan 3 suggest that random Rapid Antigen Tests are being conducted at Fish Stalls in the Western Province (the country's capital Colombo is in the Western Province):   - https://web.archive.org/web/20210126065207/https://colombogazette.com/2021/01/03/rapid-antigen-tests-conducted-at-fish-stalls-in-western-province/  - https://web.archive.org/web/20210126065251/https://www.newsradio.lk/local/random-tests-to-be-conducted-at-fish-stalls-markets/

Sri Lanka continues to employ a comprehensive contact tracing and isolation for its COVID 19 clusters. Targeted areas are put under (and removed) from isolation on a (near-) daily basis -- see notes for C2 through mid-December 2020 to mid-January 2021 for archived Press Releases for Isolation Area updates.    Additionally, based on a Dec 1 2020 news reports it seems that PCR and Rapid Antigen testing was expanded beyond just govt. institutes conducting them, to private workplaces conducting them regularly: "The contacts of a Covid-19 positive employee at the workplace can be referred to Rapid Antigen Tests." - https://web.archive.org/web/20210126072203/http://www.adaderana.lk/news/69606/guidelines-for-private-sector-on-carrying-out-rapid-antigen-tests    The full set of Govt issued guidelines as reported in the news report are available below:    "All employees should undergo mandatory Covid-19 symptom screening daily at the entrance of the workplace. In addition to checking the temperature.  • Any employee identified with symptoms suspicious of Covid-19 at the screening should be subjected to Rapid Antigen Test.  • A name list of employees undergoing this test and the test result must be submitted to the Epidemiology Unit (chiefepid@health.gov.lk), Regional Epidemiologist in the district and the area MOH on a daily basis.  • If the Rapid Antigen Test is positive, the Epidemiology Unit, area MOH and Regional Epidemiologist must be informed and the treatment protocol should be initiated.  • If the Rapid Antigen Test is negative, the employee should be subjected to PCR testing and should not involve in duties until results are available.  • If the PCR test is positive, the notification process (informing the Epidemiology Unit, Regional Epidemiologist and the area MOH) must be followed and the treatment protocol should be initiated.  • If the test result is negative, the employee should remain at the place of residence until the episode is settled.  • However, if the symptoms are worsening, the employee must be advised to inform the appointed focal point at the enterprise. The focal point should inform the area MOH for necessary action.  • The contacts of a Covid-19 positive employee at the workplace can be referred to Rapid Antigen Tests.  • The factories under the purview of the Board of Investment (BOI) and the Export Development Board (EDB) are instructed to conduct PCR tests as per health recommendations. However, if a factory is located in a high-risk area for Covid-19, 10 per cent of its employees can be directed to Rapid Antigen Tests."

As per AP, "It is unknown when Sri Lanka will be getting the vaccine."  - https://web.archive.org/web/20210126063028/https://apnews.com/article/sri-lanka-coronavirus-pandemic-340488c48ab372050825e70e057dd294

Jan 18 2021: Pakistan Today: "The federal Government on Friday extended the date for reopening of primary and middle schools (Class 1-8) from January 25 to February 1 after scrutiny of current Covid-19 situation in order to ensure safety of students.. Shafqat said that the government’s prior decision (to reopen schools) will be followed regarding reopening of high-and intermediate-level schools (9-12) from January 18, while universities will reopen from February 1." - https://web.archive.org/web/20210126080730/https://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2021/01/15/primary-middle-schools-to-remain-closed-till-feb-1-shafqat/    "Punjab Schools To Open From Jan 18, Universities From Feb 1: Minister" - https://web.archive.org/web/20210126080625/https://whenwherehow.pk/2021/01/04/punjab-schools-to-open-from-jan-18-universities-from-feb-1-minister/    "Pakistan Schools Begin Phased Reopening ... Pakistan has started reopening schools in phases after about two months of closure despite a steady increase in infections and fatalities from the coronavirus. Authorities said in the first phase, classes for senior grade students will reopen, while junior class will be reopened from February 1st." - https://web.archive.org/web/20210126080912/https://www.republicworld.com/world-news/pakistan-news/pakistan-schools-begin-phased-reopening.html

No change from the policy as reported on Jan 18, 2021: https://web.archive.org/web/20210126080730/https://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2021/01/15/primary-middle-schools-to-remain-closed-till-feb-1-shafqat/

"Is a negative COVID-19 test (PCR and/or serology) required for entry? [Yes]  Pakistan’s Ministry of National Health Services, Regulation, and Coordination issued updated guidelines for arriving passengers on January 5. The Pakistani Civil Aviation Authority’s (PCAA) latest implementation guidelines began November 20.  On January 5 the PCAA released new guidelines for travelers arriving from the UK and South Africa.  Keep current on your airline’s requirements for initiating a journey to Pakistan.  All passengers are required to install and register on the Pass Track app prior to issuance of boarding pass to Pakistan at point of original embarkation (available for Android and Apple devices).  Passengers who do not have android/Apple phones and are unable to download the Pass Track app will need to enter their data on an accessible web-based form and provide a paper printout of the same prior to issuance of boarding pass to Pakistan at point of original embarkation.  All passengers will also have to fill out a health declaration form (HDF) before landing (see Questionnaire for Travelers).  Countries are categorized into Category A, B, or C primarily based on epidemiological risk assessment, reviewed every two weeks by the Ministry of National Health Services, Regulations, and Coordination.  Travelers arriving from Category A countries:  No COVID-19 RT-PCR (real-time, reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction) test required before or after travel.  Travelers arriving from Category B countries (on January 20, 2021 the United States falls under this category):  Show proof of a negative RT-PCR test result taken within 96 hours of commencement of original travel.  Travelers arriving from Category C countries:  Show proof of a negative RT-PCR test result taken within 96 hours of commencement of original travel. All arriving from a Category C country will also take a mandatory RT-PCR test upon arrival in Pakistan.  Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry? [Yes]  Upon arrival, all travelers will line up six feet (two meters) apart and undergo thermo-screening by thermo-guns and/or thermo-scanners.  Detailed information for arriving passengers is available in the Guidelines for International Passengers Arriving at Airports in Pakistan.  For the most up-to-date information regarding visa extensions for residents and/or tourists, please visit here."    "Are U.S. citizens required to quarantine? [No]  Symptomatic travelers will be required to take a COVID-19 RT-PCR test and its results submitted to the designated Pakistani authorities within 48 hours of arrival.  In cases found positive for COVID-19 based on a test upon arrival, travelers may be required to comply with isolation procedures.  Asymptomatic travelers should be provided with written instructions and guidelines for home quarantine for 14 days."    - https://web.archive.org/web/20210126081727/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

"Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry? [Yes]  Upon arrival, all travelers will line up six feet (two meters) apart and undergo thermo-screening by thermo-guns and/or thermo-scanners.    [travelers from certain countries are required to] Show proof of a negative RT-PCR test result taken within 96 hours of commencement of original travel."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210126081727/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Tests are available for anyone symptomatic. Anyone asymptomatic can also get tested but need to cite specific circumstances.     "Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in [Pakistan]? [Yes] Both viral antigen and RT-PCR tests are available.  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? [Yes] Currently labs are regularly able to provide COVID-19 test results within the required timeframe.  Testing is currently available both to individuals with symptoms as well as for asymptomatic individuals who need a test for administrative reasons, such as for preflight."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210126081727/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Tests seem to be available for any one with symptoms. However, asymptomatic individuals can also request a test for "administrative reasons, such as for preflight". Given the narrow scope for asymptomatic individuals to get a tested, i am marking this as a 2 (instead of a 3)    "Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Pakistan? Yes.  Both viral antigen and RT-PCR tests are available.  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes.  Currently labs are regularly able to provide COVID-19 test results within the required timeframe.  Testing is currently available both to individuals with symptoms as well as for asymptomatic individuals who need a test for administrative reasons, such as for preflight." https://web.archive.org/web/20210126081727/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

"Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Pakistan? Yes.  Both viral antigen and RT-PCR tests are available.  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes.  Currently labs are regularly able to provide COVID-19 test results within the required timeframe.  Testing is currently available both to individuals with symptoms as well as for asymptomatic individuals who need a test for administrative reasons, such as for preflight.  Test results are regularly available in English."  - https://web.archive.org/web/20210209080012/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

In Pakistan, provinces carry out contact tracing, but the process is assisted and centrally collated, and the NCOC (National Command Operation Center) is aware of the tests done for potentially infected persons and as part of contact tracing. (source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210126092232/https://thediplomat.com/2020/07/inside-pakistans-covid-19-contact-tracing/)    Among the recent Standard Operating Procedures by the NCOC (at https://ncoc.gov.pk/sop.php; https://web.archive.org/web/20210126092351/https://ncoc.gov.pk/sop.php) the definition of Frontline Workers was formally established: https://web.archive.org/web/20210126091210/https://ncoc.gov.pk/sop/80.%20Approved%20Definition%20-%20FLHCWs%20FS.pdf  Amongst the criteria, point 2 was: "b. Public health staff involved with test, track and quarantine. These are staff visiting patients at home, collecting data and samples from home."  --- Indicating that testing and tracking is a key component of Pakistan's health infrastructure and COVID19 response.    Further, among the recent notices NCOC also released a detailed guidance sheet for how to identify "contact" and track symptomatic and asymptomatic cases for incoming International Passengers - https://web.archive.org/web/20210126091949/https://ncoc.gov.pk/sop/79.%2020210105%20International%20Passengers%20Arriving%20at%20Airports%20in%20Pakistan_4805.pdf (dated: Jan 5 2021)    finally, from the later part of 2020,  (dated Sep 26 2020), NCOC release guidelines for how to "Home Quarantine during COVID 19 Out-break", in which it lays out steps to identify "contacts" during a home quarantine, and proceed with testing for those who come in "contact" with COVID-19. -- https://web.archive.org/web/20210126092010/https://ncoc.gov.pk/sop/66.%2020200926%20Guidelines%20for%20Home%20Quarantine%20for%20Contacts%20and%20International%20Travelers_0403.pdf

No change from prior notes. NCOC continue to engage in coordinating contact tracing functions carried out by local provinces in Pakistan. (source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210126092232/https://thediplomat.com/2020/07/inside-pakistans-covid-19-contact-tracing/)

No change from prior notes. NCOC continue to engage in coordinating contact tracing functions carried out by local provinces in Pakistan.    In Pakistan, provinces carry out contact tracing, but the process is assisted and centrally collated, and the NCOC (National Command Operation Center) is aware of the tests done for potentially infected persons and as part of contact tracing. (source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210126092232/https://thediplomat.com/2020/07/inside-pakistans-covid-19-contact-tracing/)
"Masks are required to be worn when in public, and violators could be fined by law enforcement." - https://web.archive.org/web/20210126081727/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No change in this general policy since Oct: "The Pakistan National Command and Operation Centre (NCOC) announced October 28, 2020, that, effective immediately, to prevent the spread of COVID-19, masks must be worn when in public, countrywide. Islamabad Capital Territory (ICT) ordered masks must be worn in public places, including bazaars, shopping malls, and restaurants or while using public transport.  ICT’s announcement warns those not following the order may be subject to legal action." - https://web.archive.org/web/20210126081727/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

- https://web.archive.org/web/20210209080012/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  "The Pakistan National Command and Operation Centre (NCOC) announced October 28, 2020, that, effective immediately, to prevent the spread of COVID-19, masks must be worn when in public, countrywide. "Vaccines are currently not available in Pakistan, as the country has not yet procured these." - https://web.archive.org/web/20210126081727/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Has the Government of Pakistan approved a COVID-19 vaccine for use? [Yes] The Government of Pakistan has approved two vaccines for emergency use, AstraZeneca and SinoPharm.  Vaccines are currently not available in Pakistan, as the country has not yet procured these    - https://web.archive.org/web/20210126081727/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

https://web.archive.org/web/20210209082015/https://www.thenews.com.pk/latest/783982-first-coronavirus-jab-administered-in-pakistan    Vaccine: Sinovax; Group: Health Care workers    "First coronavirus jab administered in Pakistan: Prime Minister Imran Khan supervising the first coronavirus shot as Pakistan kicks off its vaccination drive, on February 2, 2021  The first coronavirus vaccine was administered in Pakistan on Tuesday, given to a healthcare worker in Islamabad.    "I congratulate [all those present here] for working at great speed to import a vaccine. We also thank China for gifting us 500,000 vaccines," he said.    The premier also sought to assure the nation that the vaccine distribution across the various provinces is being done in a "just" manner. "No one should think we distributed more vaccines in a given province than in others."    He stressed the importance of healthcare workers getting the shot as "all over the world it is the healthcare workers that are most at risk".  Provinces to begin vaccination drive tomorrow."
